column2: Inequality Data Explorer of the World Inequality Database

column6: France
subtitle

The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.
column7: Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

column2: Income share of the top 10% (before tax)
column6: This is the income of the richest 10% as a share of total income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.
column7: Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

column2: Income share of the top 1% (before tax)
column6: This is the income of the richest 1% as a share of total income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.
column7: Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

column2: Income share of the top 0.1% (before tax)
column6: This is the income of the richest 0.1% as a share of total income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.
column7: Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

column2: Income share of the top 0.01% (before tax)
column6: This is the income of the richest 0.01% as a share of total income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.
column7: Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

column2: Income share of the top 0.001% (before tax)
column6: This is the income of the richest 0.001% as a share of total income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.
column7: Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

column6: P90 and P10 are the levels of income below which 90% and 10% of the population live, respectively. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.
column7: Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

column6: The P90/P50 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the richest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that someone just falling in the richest tenth of the population has twice the median income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.
column7: Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

column6: The P50/P10 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the poorest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that the median income is two times higher than that of someone just falling in the poorest tenth of the population. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.
column7: Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

column6: The Palma ratio is the share of total income of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.
column7: Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

P90 and P10 are the levels of income below which 90% and 10% of the population live, respectively. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

The P90/P50 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the richest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that someone just falling in the richest tenth of the population has twice the median income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

The P50/P10 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the poorest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that the median income is two times higher than that of someone just falling in the poorest tenth of the population. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.
The Palma ratio is the share of total income of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and cash benefits.

The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the wealth distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

This is the wealth of the richest 10% as a share of total wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

This is the wealth of the richest 1% as a share of total wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

This is the wealth of the richest 0.1% as a share of total wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

This is the wealth of the richest 0.01% as a share of total wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

This is the wealth of the richest 0.001% as a share of total wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

P90 and P10 are the levels of wealth below which 90% and 10% of the population live, respectively. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

The P90/P50 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the richest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that someone just falling in the richest tenth of the population has twice the median wealth. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

The P50/P10 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the poorest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that the median wealth is two times higher than that of someone just falling in the poorest tenth of the population. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

The Palma ratio is the share of total wealth of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%. Wealth is defined as the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.

P90 is the the level of income below which 90% of the population lives. P10 is the level of income below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.
	This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

P90 is the the level of income above which 10% of the population lives. P50 is the median – the level of income below which 50% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the top half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone in the middle of the distribution would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.
	This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

P50 is the median – the level of income below which 50% of the population lives. P10 is the the level of income below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the bottom half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be reach the median.
	This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

The Palma ratio is a measure of inequality: it is the share of total income of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%.
	This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.
